reviews.review_msg: Beyond me why he is still teaching at SFU.  Not a very good teacher in my opinion.  He doesn't teach material that ends up on exams.  YOu are better off just studying the textbooks on your own and just attend class for attendance.

Make sure you go over your assignments because he really doesn't seem to pay attention to the details.  He doesn't like any argument that is contrary to his opinion.  Memorize the text books instead of absorbing his opinions.

Professor Nizamani is a great guy.  He is truly committed to ensuring the success of his students and his depth of knowledge on South Asian politics is baffling.He highly encourages discussion and politely puts you in your place if you're dead wrong about something. Overall great class, learned about the actual politics not theory

HI! Haider is a great prof, very helpful and highly insightful.  His lectures can be dry but only if you haven't read the material because when you come unprepared he takes over the discussion.  He's easy on the eyes too.
Very passionate, nice man, but a little hard to follow in lecture.

Memorize the textbook.  He is absolutely boring and rambles on about history when this is a poli sci course?  He leaves little room for critical thought and argument, which is completely the opposite of what we are supposed to be doing in third year.  I don't recommend  him.

Haider knows his stuff, but is right out boring. He doesn't stick to the topic during lectures, and his assignments are always simple summaries or the readings, who doesn't challenge students. The readings are good. Bring a magazine/books to lectures to survive. Don't let this prof. discourage your from studying IS.
Nice guy but not the greatest teacher. So hard to pay attention to him talking through lecture, good thing he has good slides or everyone would fall asleep and really learn nothing.

Super nice and funny. Love him as a person, very, very hard to pay attention to though.Two hour classes can be painful. Make sure you do the readings, for the concepts in them are what make up the final. Kind of everywhere, but a fair course.
Good guy, not the best communicator, knows his material well.

very knowledgable but he makes you think the MT is easy but your in for a suprise. All the grades were within a very small range (almost all Bs and low As). oh and he takes FOREVER saying a sentence...

I will agree with previous comments, he is a very nice person BUT(BIG BUT)  he is very picky about all his historical facts etc.  Going to lectures is not enough.  Make sure you read the entire text readings, or you will be screwed on the mid-term and the final!

You will get a history course, not a political science course.  He marks hard on the exam and paper but overall is a nice guy.  Most people were in the B- range, which is unusually low for a Political Science class.
Really nice guy, very helpful. His classes do seem to stray away from the course content but he is a fair marker and an easy-going prof.

i don't know how you guys can say that haider is a good teacher. it's true that he knows his stuff, but he hardly imparts it. he doesn't correct erroneous student assertions and lets wrong and misguided discussions dominate the class. haider needs to learn how to set boundaries for students, as well as how to compile a lecture.
Really nice guy, very knowledgable about South Asia (course was int'l relations of South Asia). Apparently some students enroll in his classes just to have him as their prof.
Very nice and helpful.  Good teacher and very knowledgeable.
